Aspirin for Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎08-27-2012 11:24 PM

http://www.ahrq.gov/news/press/pr2009/aspcvdpr.htm

 

Are you taking it or has your doctor recommended that you take it?  How much?  Most recommended therapeutic dosages apparently range from 81mg (one baby aspirin) to 325mg (one regular aspirin).  My doctor recently recommended taking it daily, based on the above study recommendations, but didn't say how much.  I'm inclined to split the difference between the large dose and the small one by taking two baby aspirin, which would be half of the regular dose.  I have just been taking it sporadically over the last few years, not having heard much about it for a while.....

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

I take one regular aspirin a day because of my a-fib.  The cardiologist said that should be fine when I refused to take the stronger blood thinners.  I also take other blood thinning supplements too, so it works for me.

powerwalker2 wrote:

http://www.ahrq.gov/news/press/pr2009/aspcvdpr.htm

 

Are you taking it or has your doctor recommended that you take it?  How much?  Most recommended therapeutic dosages apparently range from 81mg (one baby aspirin) to 325mg (one regular aspirin).  My doctor recently recommended taking it daily, based on the above study recommendations, but didn't say how much.  I'm inclined to split the difference between the large dose and the small one by taking two baby aspirin, which would be half of the regular dose.  I have just been taking it sporadically over the last few years, not having heard much about it for a while.....

I have taken an 81 grain aspirin every day for years.  My doctor recommended, but I had actually been taking one for a long time before she suggested it because of the studies that suggested it helped.  Besides...one of the first things they recommend when you have a heart attack or stroke is aspirin....why not get a head start?

Talvie

‎08-28-2012 12:33 PM

I take an 81 mg aspirin every morning.  I have for years.  Heart problems run in my family from my mother's side.  Her father had a bad heart with several heart attacks during his life and I lost my brother 12 years ago, when he was only 41, to a heart attack.

 

An interesting note, there actually are no such thing as blood thinners, even though the term is used quite often.  These are actually anticoagulants.  They only prevent the blood from clotting but do not do anything to make the blood thinner than normal.  Even doctors use the term blood thinners even though, technically, it is incorrect.  I'm not saying don't use the term, because most people know what you are talking about when you say it, but just passing along another little piece of trivial knowledge.


"No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." -- Eleanor Roosevelt


Toujeo 70 units in the morning and at bedtime
Novolog 50 units with each meal
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily
Glipizide ER 5 mg daily
Neurontin (gabapentin) 300 mg three times daily (neuropathy)
Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily (hypertension)
lisinopril 40 mg daily (hypertension)
Crestor 10mg at bedtime (hypercholesterolemia)
Arthrotec 50 three times daily (Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Multivitamin daily
Aspirin 81 mg daily
Lovaza 2 gm twice daily

‎08-28-2012 01:53 PM

My endo started me on an aspirin regimen when he first saw me after diagnosis.  He told me to take 81mg a day, which I've done for the past year and a half.  It's a purely preventative measure because he said so many diabetics die from heart issues.  My labs don't reveal any cardiovascular issues.

 

You might want to check with your doctor to find out how much you should take.  Since it was recommended to you, I'm sure the doctor must have a suggestion as to the appropriate dosage for you.

Matt
Visit my personal blog - ABunchOfPricks.com

‎08-28-2012 02:20 PM

In the article, it stated:

 

A dose as low as 75 mg seems as effective as higher doses.

 

A while back, one of my docs suggested a baby aspirin a day. It is a blood "thinner" and if one is prone to internal bleeding, a higher dose may cause that. And too much of a blood thinner may lead to a brain hemmorage, another cause of stokes. (the other being blockage causing stroke or heart attack).

 

I am already on coumadin, a blood thinner, but the level is closely monitored, monthly. So no aspirin for me.

_________________________________________________

‎08-28-2012 05:00 PM - edited ‎08-28-2012 05:02 PM

Ever notice how even the aspirin commercials on TV have disclaimers these days about checking with your doctor before beginning an aspirin regimen?

 

I was really surprised when I had some blood work done before my high-risk colonoscopy and discovered I had iron deficiency anemia, because my hemoglobin numbers have always been really good.  The doctor said the most likely cause was the medications I was taking causing internal bleeding.

 

I had been taking an 81mg aspirin, plus a larger than average dose of Aleve for arthritis.  I was already taking Prevacid too, because I had problems with heartburn, possibly made worse by those meds and a couple of other things that had warnings like "take with food" and "rise mouth after inhaling".

 

I dropped the aspirin and Aleve and the ALA I was taking and started taking the ferrous sulfate my doctor prescribed.  My hemoglobin is looking much better now.  I'm back to the  81mg aspirin  and half the Aleve now.  Boy, did I miss the Aleve. So far, so good, but I will see how things are going the next time I have labs.

 

My point? Even plain old ordinary aspirin may not be good for everybody and may contribute to relatively serious side effects.  Talking to your doctor is a good idea.  Even then, you may run into problems.  I'm back on the aspirin, but a little more watchful.

"Molly" (aka mollythed)
Type 2 diabetes diagnosed in 1995, now managed with Lantus, Novolog and Metformin; diet and exercise.
My late husband had diabetes. My three adult sons also have type 2 diabetes.
